page.title: 07River Coquet at Acklington
page.content: The{River Coquet}is surely one of the prettiest rivers in England. It begins in the Cheviot Hills and it flows into the sea at Amble. It is a well known salmon river and fishing is a popular sport on the stretch of river beside Acklington. Birds using the river include kingfishers, herons, ducks and swans (we even had a pelican for a while) and small mammals such as voles and water rats are very common. Otters used to be common but mink are more numerous now.{Acklington Dam}was built in 1778 to provide water for a tin & iron foundry which opened in 1775. Some people claim that the dam drove the salmon out of the Coquet and so a fish ladder was built beside the dam. The foundry became a woollen mill in 1791 and then a dye factory in 1916. Today the "Dye House" is in fact a group of four private dwellings.
